Blue Prince stands out for how confidently it merges genres and concepts that would usually not fit together. It’s part roguelike, part puzzle game, part exploration game, part mystery, and somehow all sides are handled with equal care. Runs feel varied but never too chaotic, and the game's design keeps you thinking several steps ahead about all of these elements without any single one ever becoming overwhelming.

Each visit through the estate feels distinct. The way rooms connect, the order in which they’re revealed, and the clues you uncover all combine to form a slow, deliberate rhythm. The game's well-balanced pacing is what makes it work so well, as you’re always discovering something new at just the right time to keep you curious and coming back for more. It’s a core loop that rewards attention to detail, as opposed to speed.

The puzzles themselves are sharp and consistent. Solutions make sense once you see them, and the logic behind each challenge is clear. Clues can appear in the same room or several rooms apart, which encourages careful observation and note-taking instead of simply brute forcing solutions. Even the navigation itself works as a puzzle, as choosing where to place rooms and how to connect paths to reach your end "goal", while carefully considering how you spend your resources from room to room, turns exploration into another layer of problem-solving. 

Although some of the game’s RNG can sometimes cripple or entirely kill runs altogether, the design usually gives you enough strategic flexibility to adapt. Careful planning and smart room placement can often turn bad draws into a manageable challenge.

The presentation and atmosphere ties everything together. The subdued visuals and sound design reinforce the game's tone without trying to distract from the rest of it. The game's art style also works in that it subtly creates clarity and contrast to help you find items and other interactivity prompts, working for the game's structure not only aesthetically, but also functionally. There’s a sense of mystery that builds naturally, with the story unfolding through implication rather than exposition. I have already achieved the "main goal" of the game, yet haven’t finished its full narrative yet, but what I've already discovered feels intentional and cohesive.

The visuals are also pretty nice, and the story is far from boring, though it takes a while to put all the pieces together, which is fitting for this game.

The concept is pretty straight forward: You inherited a mansion, but under the condition that you have to find room 46 in it. The mansion changes its rooms every day, so you have to stay the night outside in a tent and start over each day in order to find room 46.
Finishing that part of the game won't take too long, but then there is so much more to find. There are hidden things and clues in pretty much every room you go to, and beyond that. It allows for going through this mansion day after day without it getting too boring. At the time of writing this review, I spent about 70 hours over a course of about 40 in-game days, so roughly 2 hours per in-game day (though I did take my time on a lot of stuff, definitely can go faster). It was only at the last few in-game days that I felt like, yeah, I've seen pretty much all of it and just want to unlock these final secrets for the story. Which I did.

For completionist sake, I'm only halfway the achievements, but most of what I still need to do are new-game challenges and speedrun stuff. When I pick this game back up (and I will), I definitely will get those done and 100% this game.

It can feel very frustrating feeling you've figured out a solution to one of the bigger puzzles of the game and then due to chance, it takes another few hours to confirm/resolve that idea because you just don't get the rooms you need. 

Overall, the game works best at the beginning when everything is a mystery and any room or layout presents some form of progression or new hint in the greater mysteries of the game, and starts to spin its wheels a bit later when the only mysteries left to solve are the more elaborate and spread out ones.

This game quickly went from an enjoyable experience to one of my favorite games of all time. This game innovates not just for the sake of creating something new (which it succeeds at) but for the sake of its core theme. This theme runs through the game like an artery spilling its experience into not just the narrative but the gameplay. This is why the game is so incredible, it manages to unite its narrative and gameplay to such an effective degree that the message is not just read, or heard, or watched. It is PLAYED. This is why it is so disheartening to see so many negative reviews of this masterpiece, where many people treat core messages of the game as flaws when it is clear they did not come to this game ready to experience and listen. This is not to say every negative review is undeserved, there were many technical issues that I was largely spared from. There especially was a period of updates about a month after release that introduced some pretty rough bugs regarding saving, Getting burned by one of those, or the brief period that saves could get corrupted, would be experience ruining without a doubt but these issues are largely fixed.

The game very quickly goes so far as to state the core theme at you: you find the most when you are not focused on looking for one thing specifically, just when you are committed to looking in general. Secrets are secrets because they are good at hiding from those who are looking for them, not necessarily that they are hiding from everyone.

 When playing Blue Prince you must remember is that there are many paths to where you need to go, never fixate and take them as they come. If you fish or doggedly chase one solution you will not only undermine your own experience, but also your ability to make progress toward your own solution since you will be missing things you did not even know you are missing. 

Of course there are random elements, it is a ROGUELIKE. There are also myriad ways to mitigate the randomness, which you will not find if instead of exploring in the exploration puzzle game you instead decide to bash your head into the wall of trying to find one specific thing over and over again. The fact that it sucks to avoid exploration in favor of obsession is not a FLAW of the game, it is a FEATURE. It is the MESSAGE. The game is telling you, screaming at you, to embrace occasional ambiguity and take a breath. Look around and when the moment arises to actualize and test a theory you will be ready and perhaps more informed and more well-equipped to accomplish it. You may even find a way to make it easier to manipulate probability to your advantage. The only thing in the entire game after 100% and challenge runs that I could think of that could use more ability to manipulate the probability around would be [spoiler] the vault keys, which due to not being tied to the room system require a very specific and limited set of tools to make it more likely they be found [/spoiler].

With all that said, this game is a 10/10, but I must remind anyone who made it through this review that a 10/10 does not mean that 10 out of 10 people who play it will like it, it means it is extremely effective at being what it is and saying what it needs to say. If you are not prepared to listen then perhaps pass on the game, and come back to it either when you are. With curiosity, patience, and a tolerance for ambiguity this game has more to say than how to beat it, it can have you re-examine how you are behaving in life as well. If you are unable to relax when playing games, not in a good place to accept losses or failures when they come to you, or for some reason morally opposed to using a notebook this game might not be one you enjoy.

Blue Prince's mysteries and secrets to uncover are by far the most impressive I've ever seen in any kind of videogame. It goes ridiculously deep, and it is incredibly satisfying to keep unveiling new things and digging deeper. It's on the level of needing dozens of pages of notes and likely close to a hundred hours to get to the bottom of it all, and it is an incredibly rewarding experience. 


However, its deep puzzles are almost antithetical to the heavily RNG-dependant and grindy roguelite gameplay. The gameplay loop can be very enjoyable and engaging until you reach the first "ending", but after that, it only gets increasingly more masochistic, as the secrets have increasingly more difficult steps, where just to figure them out, you'll need a lot of luck just to get the pieces you need in a run to align. It doesn't help that the game really doesn't have that many tools to impactfully mitigate RNG.


I'm 100% convinced the ideal way to play this game is to go through it as normal until a bit after the first ending, and when things start getting annoying, download mods to give you infinite resources and items, so you're free to just focus on solving things and testing out your theories. 


This game would be great enough on its own even if it featured none of the roguelite gameplay at all, as the puzzles and mysteries are enough to justify playing it. The ideal solution would be more ways to consistently avoid RNG, but as that likely won't happen, mods can do the trick, and I really wish they were there when I played the game.

Blue Prince is such a fascinating game to me in concept: an exploratory puzzle roguelike? Say less.
In execution, however? I think this game is as good as the concept can realistically get, but there are some fundamental flaws to the genre combination that can't be overlooked. If you go in completely blind (which I did), there will be a time when you leave the 'everything is new and wonderous' phase, go through the 'I have so many clues with no puzzles and puzzles with no clues' phase, then finally enter the 'I know what I need to do but the game is not letting me do it' phase. There will also be runs in which you don't make any progress towards the end goal of reaching room 46, feeling like you wasted 15-45 minutes without having drafted any new room types to explore, discovered any new multi-room puzzles, or made any connections with clues you do have.
To compliment the game, however, the first 8-10 hours was some of the most engrossing gameplay I have ever experienced. When everything is so new, taking the time to write down any pattern, set of numbers, or other out-of-place thing you can imagine is super engaging. Some clues will be obvious - they solve puzzles in the room you find the clue in - other clues will show you what they open up but it's elsewhere in the manor, and some clues are just more lore and worldbuilding texts, but you don't know that yet. There's some puzzles for everyone - some puzzles test your logic and reasoning skills, others your math ability, more test your 3D spatial awareness, some to test how well you've learned the world around you, and others how many times like bashing your head against a wall until something works.
I have only beaten one run, to be fair, and was after an extremely lucky two-run sequence where my penultimate run had a nearly perfect setup for my next run, both in terms in what I learned towards reaching room 46 and what little I was allowed to carry over into the following run. I know that there is a lot that I do not know - my notebook has plenty of pages of loose clues, puzzles, and theories - but I'm perfectly happy leaving those mysteries unsolved having enjoyed my time with this game already.
It also took me way too long, well after knowing the game was about drafting rooms in a building, that the game's title of Blue Prince was a play on words of Blueprints. That's how good of a game this is; the puzzles start before you've bought the game.

I will be honest with you, even though I had numerous people tell me that this was 'my type of game' I found myself avoiding it for a while because I didn't like the way it looked in pictures, my brain told me at a glance that it was 'probably just okay' and I didn't delve far enough to figure out what kind of game it was. It conjured ideas of walking simulators like Myst that I loathed (sorry to the Myst fans) and I didn't give it a fair shot.

But boy was a wrong.

This game... it devours you. What begins as mild curiosity and a satisfying game loop that is unique to roguelikes, becomes an obsession of having to know the solution to the next puzzle. Becomes suspicion at every little design element, wondering if its that clue you've been desperate to find. 

I was taking notes for the first time in years. I was writing down things I thought -vaguely- sounded like it was important. The game starts on a Monday. Is that relevant? Not yet but it -could- be and that's enough. 

The game has depth, the story you uncover is intriguing, the replayability is high and when you think you've found everything... guess what, there's probably -still- about twenty things that you've missed. People still believe they haven't found every puzzle there is and if you think getting all the achievements means the game is over then you are laughably wrong.

There's only one negative thing to say about this game, two if I'm very generous with finding faults:

1. There will be no localisation. It depresses me to say it because I would love for this to be available for everyone, but the vast majority of the overarching big puzzles involve wordplay, sentence structure or hidden messages that only work in the original English. The creator has said that localisation for those reasons is pretty impossible, and I get it. It still sucks though.

2. The game does not hold your hand in the slightest. Things it presents to you as the rules of puzzles you will later discover are lies fed to you on purpose. You will second guess if that clue you found is relevant, you will wonder what you are missing if you keep doing the same satisfying loop you're used to. Some rooms will -never- show up, if you don't interpret a note and understand its meaning. The game requires patience and a willingness to engage with it on its level to fully enjoy it. The pay off for completing a puzzle you've been thinking about in the back of your mind for hours while you play is amazing if you let it, but I know I have friends for whom the frustration of not knowing what to do right away would be the reason they stop playing. 

I could gush about this game for much longer than this, but I'm struggling to think of more to say without spoilering any solutions to puzzles as to highlight what I love about this game would mean to give specific examples and moments that made me love it in the first place.

All I can say is, if you love puzzles, if you want a game to really sink your teeth into and obsess over, this is the game for you.

And if you are just an admirer of good games, play it anyway. There's a wiki that you can use to solve all the puzzles for you and the base gameplay is really enjoyable. At least then you will have experienced the vision of the game and even minorly understand how fantastically well put together it is. It genuinely breaks my heart that this isn't the right genre of game to win a Game of the Year award and that not enough people will give it a chance. 

It also breaks my heart that I can't play it again right now. Maybe when I'm old and have forgotten it all. I'm rooting for you old age!

I was legitimately on the last run I was willing to give it, I said "I will do it one more time and if it's not fun then I am giving up." Thankfully, I hit some solid luck on that very last run and the game opened up into the mid-game and things became a lot easier to navigate and I was given a lot more freedom to explore in ways that I actually found fun.

I think there's some sort of balance issue here where the early game is such a slog to get through before you get to the good part of the game. I don't know how to fix that, but the fact that it is almost entirely dependent on RNG and luck made it really frustrating to get through.

That being said, I am glad I did push through, because the rest of the game is quite fun and very unique from a puzzle game perspective, and it has some extremely clever puzzles (and some extremely stupid ones, I stand by that).

If you're a big fan of puzzle games and love a good challenge and don't mind being stuck for a couple hours on end with no real progress to be made, by all means try this game. If you're not that into puzzle games, you're probably going to hate this. Or maybe you'll get a bit luckier than I did, and you'll love it much quicker than I did.

I do think some of the puzzles were weak and silly at best, but they were outnumbered by other very well constructed puzzles that spanned such a broad part of the game that felt very satisfying to finally link together. The game absolutely does not respect your time for a lot of actions, which is frustrating, and some of the puzzles are pretty stupid and also waste your time, which is frustrating, but the overall experience was positive and the negatives were outweighed by the positives of finally piecing together the million and a half clues you stumbled across in the past 30 hours of gameplay.

As you can see, I broke past that 8 hour frustration zone and now have almost 70 hours in the game, and I am glad I pushed through. But do be aware that this game is definitely not for everyone.

One of the best games I've played in the last couple years, easily. However, it is one of those that is best experienced whilst knowing as little as possible about it beforehand, and the game's rather expansive. Therefore, I'll go over just a few bullet points that I'd consider to be actually important to know before getting into the game; otherwise, I risk accidentally creating an entire blog just centered around this game instead of a review.

[list]
[*] Obviously I'm recommending the game, I'd recommend it to anyone, but I also recognize that it's certainly not for everybody. If puzzle games just aren't your cup of tea, this one's gonna be a hard pass; same goes for any RNG elements (described in more detail in the next paragraph). Don't feel bad for passing on this game if you know you won't like its core elements! It's better than torturing yourself with gameplay you can't find any fun in.

[*] RNG. It's a big factor here and it will be, mostly, always as you play. The best comparison I can make in this regard is Balatro: you can figure out many ways to manipulate the game's inherent randomness to your favor, but in most cases, probability can still just decide to be a pain in the arse and screw you over anyway. IMHO there comes a point where it becomes more of a nuisance rather than the drive to widen the scope of your exploration and I do wish it were at least slightly addressed. Still, it does definitely get better as you keep playing.

[*] Unless your memory is insanely brilliant, you will need to keep notes in one form or another. The earlier the better. Note down everything that seems important, even if just slightly -- you can always erase useless notes later! You don't have to be overly sophisticated about it, the Steam overlay's notekeeping tool does the job perfectly fine, and I see many people getting by just by saving screenshots. My Blue Prince notes may or may not have about 20 organized sections with occassional diegetic-sounding remarks for immersion -- but you definitely don't need to go to such lengths.

[*] [b][u]You can only save and quit in between days.[/u][/b] You won't be able to save your progress on the current day, leave, then return and finish it later, The game will just force you to end the day before allowing you to save. This is one of the few elements in BP that I would consider an outright oversight -- whilst I understand that saving progress mid-day is a technical challenge, I just think it really should be a thing. Days can sometimes last for a couple hours, and many aren't gonna be able to play for that long uninterrupted.

[*] Lastly, something I believe should be made clear: [b][u]there is no time limit for reaching Room 46[/u][/b], despite what the intro may imply. I don't know why they wrote it this way and I don't think that the sense of urgency it instills in a new player is beneficial. Don't be deathly afraid of "wasted" days and don't be afraid to finish a day early if you think you need to.
[/list]

These, I believe, are the primary aspects you will need to contend with during your playthrough. If any of them sound like a bad time -- you may not really enjoy Blue Prince (though, if it's just one and it's not the RNG, I'd still suggest you give it a go!), but if they all sound fine, then [u]definitely[/u] give it a go! There is a reason this game's getting nominated for and winning awards, and it stands firm in a couple of my Steam Awards nominations. Well done, Dogubomb. Really well bloody done.

[b]"Blue Prince" attempts to merge the roguelike genre with the world of puzzles, and for the most part it succeeds. Its concept feels refreshing and unique: you draw floor plans and reshape the manor differently in every run. The visuals are charming, cleverly color‑coded to aid gameplay, and the game is packed with mysteries, tools, and secrets to uncover. The lore is surprisingly deep and well written. There are many nice roguelike elements such as upgrading rooms, gradually acquiring rare floor plans, and unlocking new paths.
However, these strengths are often overshadowed by the currency system. Having large amounts of allowance (money) and stars can make the game significantly easier, to the point where other mechanics lose importance. The inclusion of repetitive puzzles (like the parlor and billiard) and the heavy reliance on strong English skills may also frustrate some players. The plot feels fragmented, and the lack of major events reduces motivation. Still, "Blue Prince" remains an authentic, distinctive experience with strong replay value—especially appealing to fans of puzzles and roguelikes.


Manometer: 7/10[/b]


The good
- Inspiring concept. A clever blend of roguelike mechanics and puzzle design. The idea of an ever‑shifting manor that you reshape each run is creative and engaging. Architects and design enthusiasts will especially appreciate it.
- Beautiful 3D graphics. Sketchy yet clean aesthetics strike a nice balance—minimal detail without feeling empty. The color‑coding approach is excellent, allowing players to quickly recognize elements after a few runs.
- Rogue like elements has problems, but some good ideas too. Building a deck of rooms, upgrading plans, acquiring rarer ones, and unlocking tools and paths adds depth. Room synergies are smartly designed, encouraging experimentation. Each run offers new opportunities, making the game highly replayable. Unfortunately, progress depends too heavily on currency (money and stars), which can overshadow strategic play.
- Mysteries everywhere. Logs, hidden paths, rare items, and even rooms outside the manor keep exploration exciting. Tools often have unexpected uses, and puzzles require combining elements from different locations, ensuring long‑term discovery
- Well‑written texts. Logs and books scattered throughout the manor carry a poetic tone and often hide secrets. The in‑game guidebooks are a nice touch, offering new players helpful strategies.
- Strong atmosphere. From the start, the manor feels eerie and otherworldly, drawing you into its mysteries.
- Polished control mechanics. Simple, responsive controls and well‑designed menus make repeated play smooth and frustration‑free.
- Although storytelling is questionable and it's really difficult to uncover the whole plot, the lore is very rich, symbolic and layered, exploring the manor’s history, the region, and the protagonist’s predecessors.

The bad
- Although it has a good structure of interconnected puzzles and some nice rogue like elements, the ability to form your own deck is overlooked. The opportunities to upgrade floor plans or draw new ones are rare. Also allowance and observatory are way to important. Progress often comes not from mastering mechanics or building a strong deck, but simply from accumulating money and stars. This undermines strategic depth and makes the game easier over time.
- Puzzle accessibility. Many puzzles lack universal logic, relying instead on real‑world knowledge. For example, billiards requires mathematical reasoning, while others demand strong English comprehension (like interpreting paintings). I had no problem with billiard, but ss a non‑native English speaker, I found some puzzles tedious (like the annoying gallery one), which limits the game’s audience.
- Putting in there two, not so creative, puzzles (parlor, billiard) that you have to play hundreds of times is tiring and after a while they lose interest. The parlor, in particular, is dull yet essential for acquiring gems, and it cannot be skipped.
- Fragmented, questionable storytelling. While the lore is rich, the narrative feels scattered. Connecting plot pieces requires many runs and methodical effort. Early on, players may spend hours without understanding their goals or motivations. The absence of major events further weakens engagement, and many players may abandon the effort to understand the story and simply continue playing it for its interesting gameplay.

In the end, I believe this game is going to disappoint you, the real question is whether the journey is going to be worth it.

It is weird to be using rogue-lite elements for a puzzle game. You’re given a random set of rooms each run and have to hope that what you get includes something that will allow you to progress the game. Early on this works surprisingly well, as the player I didn’t just get the mental challenge of solving a puzzle but also the little dopamine rush of winning a gamble each time a room I needed came up in the draw. Early game there were a lot of clues to follow, a lot of rooms that hadn’t been explored, so every run always felt like it had given me *something* to progress me further. But, as the game progressed and I followed more and more trails of clues to their conclusion, there were fewer useful rooms for me to draw, I started having runs that felt like they were useless and this did not mesh well with the fact that this game does *NOT* respect your time. Unskippable cutscenes, mandatory backtracking, slow animations, if felt atmospheric when I had two or three hypothesis I could test in a run, but when I had to go through two or three runs just to test a single hypothesis it started feeling like a pointless grind without an end in sight.

That said, I don’t regret buying this game and I would still suggest it to other players because in my opinion the ride was worth the fall. The rooms are intriguingly crafted, the world beyond the mansion fills out piece by piece in interesting ways, forming a picture of the world that is familiar yet novel. Most importantly there are narrative plateaus, where the player has enough information to feel like they’ve got a complete story even if they didn’t reach the final ending, it gives a stopping point where you can set the game aside and still feel like you’ve accomplished something. 

Which is what I did. Maybe I’ll pick it up again later, but for now I’m happy with the milestones that I’ve reached.

PS. This game does lean pretty heavily on some English/American cultural norms for its puzzles, some I might even say that some are specifically upper-middle class English/American norms. If you don’t live in one of these two nations you might have some undue hardships solving some of these puzzles.

Okay, In short, Blue Prince is a fantastic mix of roguelike and puzzle genre and I absolutely recommend anyone play it and give it a try. However, the game is absolutely not for everyone which is very clear when experiencing it and its mechanics and depth of puzzles. But those who want to see what is over the horizon will get a lot out of it, especially if you play past the initial "credits". It is a truly remarkable and unique game. the RNG will get annoying and it will frustrate you, but  its not the end of the world. You can make up for it, the game has plenty of tools to turn things in your favour. Play it as blind as you possibly can. 

Now, for the long of it. This will contain some spoilers. 

This first layer of Blue Prince is where your approach to the game is the MOST important part. I had to actually see what other people were saying about this game and what kind of mindset I "Should" have after i had started playing it because I was just confused and getting nowhere. I was convinced the roguelike aspect of the game was the major defining mechanic of it, and was just relying on getting a good run to reach the end. I had to shift my approach to the game and was more focused on taking time and finding pieces throughout the rooms, what synergies they have together, what all of these memos, notes, and cryptic paintings mean. I started to take A LOT of notes, at this time of writing I have nearly 700 screenshots of notes. I would plan out more optimal paths, unlock different things to make the game easier, discover things that wouldn't even be addressed until AFTER you see the credits roll. The depth of the puzzles is immense, and when things "click" and you figure it out, it feels great. All of this made the game more satisfying, and frustrating to play. I absolutely have a love hate relationship with this game, it has outstandingly high highs, but when I would go several IRL days of a week making absolutely no progress and have to go to bed feeling like i got nowhere. It sucks a lot and is probably Blue Princes biggest flaw. But I will comment on that a bit later, the main part of the first layer was figuring things out that get you to the antechamber (or room 46) more easily, it feels very hard at this stage of the game, to some people its basically the entire game, and ends when they reach it. But the more time you take, the more new rooms you draft and the more puzzles you put together, you will make getting to that room easier and easier, it almost feels [b]Obsessive[/b] with how badly you want to reach it. and eventually, you will find those [spoiler] levers [/spoiler] and you will reach that door, and see the credits roll. 

But there is still so much left unanswered. From this point on is the "real" game, throughout the first part of the game you will find notes about the story, the characters, lots of environmental story telling littered throughout the game, you will probably hear about the different realms and cities, about Simon's mother, about Herbert Sinclair and the life he lived, so many things like that. The story itself is its own puzzle, which I find fantastic. Some people have said getting to room 46 was the most fun of the game for them, but for me its everything after it, or the "mid game". Reaching room 46 was initially a difficult feat, but during this part of the game I had done it dozens of times, sometimes even ignoring it just so I could find other things instead and reach the next goal I was chasing. Unfortunately this is where the games flaws really begin to set in strongly. there are certain specific conditions you will need to meet at this stage to progress towards what your current "goals" are, Some are pretty easy to do, and some are just entirely reliant on "getting lucky on what you draft". I swear to god, in all of my time playing this game, I had never ONCE EVER gotten the pump room to spawn immediately next to or relatively close to the boiler room. the only way I solved the [spoiler] resevoir puzzle [/spoiler] was SIGNIFICANTLY later into the game using the [spoiler] data packets [/spoiler]. This game will really feel like its kicking your teeth in sometimes, to get 3-4 ranks into a run, get too many dead ends or lock yourself out and have to restart, not draft the room you wanted that day, run out of steps, again, and again. Yes, this is the point of the game and it will get significantly easier to mitigate this further along (by the end of the game, money was so easy to acquire that I could buy out every single store every single run) but when you are just so absolutely close to finally reaching that thing you wanted to see or try to POTENTIALLY solve something you've been sitting on for ages, just to fall over right before the finish line just really takes it out of you, I would often take breaks from the game during those moments with how bad it could get. This is probably the main reason why i have over 90 hours in this game. But even still, you will persist. The puzzles and depth keeps going and so does your ever expanding list of leads and notes. You will think to yourself, [b]Does it never end?[/b], truly you have no idea, so you keep going, and once you've found a certain amount of "things" and unlock some more late game mechanics, you will finally reach the late game, the final layer. 

This was the absolute most difficult part of the game for me, and where I had to rely on hints because the puzzles  and leads are so absurdly cryptic and rely on your knowledge of many different things I felt insanely lost quite a handful of times at this stage of the game, and I don't blame anyone else who does. There are a handful of sections of this game that really feel like you have to be touched by an elder god to truly understand them, or just read more old English literature. (and maybe understand a bit more about chess). I was very taken aback by the idea that there was still more to go, I was convinced the "mid game" section I had been playing all this time would lead to the end. but Blue Prince has many things hidden behind its doors. Despite how difficult the remaining puzzles were to solve, some of my favourite moments in the game occur during this section. mainly the [spoiler] throne room [/spoiler] and the process of getting to it which i thought was cool as fuck. The final section of the game is genuinely fascinating and feels like the game testing your knowledge for getting absolutely this far especially those who pay lots of attention to detail, however its still in the same line of incredibly difficult and cryptic puzzles that could take legitimate hours upon hours to solve, involving a lot of days and resets in game, it feels somewhat tedious and I feel like it could've been handled slightly better. 

What I loved the most was the journey, I played this game with the help of my Partner for a majority of it, we would solve puzzles together and note things down, come up with solutions to the current things we were stuck on. (she did most of the billiard puzzles cause I suck at math) It's a game I'm truly never going to forget. It reminds me a lot of Outer Wilds, which is one of the greatest games I have ever played, it is probably the closest thing to that game ive played. (in terms of them being puzzle games that involve "repeating" mechanics and difficult puzzles). Blue Prince is a game about Obsession, the characters and especially the player will show that, I know I was obsessed to see everything this game had to offer, and I do feel left quite satisfied, yet still wanting more. 

I hope one day there will be another Blue Prince.

negative.review:
I really think I would have enjoyed this. The interesting art style, the atmosphere it evokes in the beginning. Very good first impression... for about ten minutes.

Refunded due to lack of save on quit. I have to control my game time and stop when I need to. Being forced to abandon a run I'm enjoying because there's no save feature is just not something I'm interested in.

Save on quit is an accessibility feature for many of us. I'd love to give this another try if such a feature were implemented, even as an option to toggle on in the accessibility settings.

The puzzle and lore elements of this game are fantastic. The art direction is beautiful. The basic gameplay mechanics are straightforward enough. I really wish I could give this game a positive review because what is good about this game is fantastic - peerless, even. 

The puzzles in this game become increasingly obscure and I would even venture out to say that some of the later-game puzzles are contrived. I, however, am a bit of a novice at puzzle games and I fully expect that those with more experience in the genre will love them. In my subjective experience, however, some of the puzzles are not forthcoming in a way that, when solved, do not fill me with feelings of reward. Rather, I am left thinking "THAT was the solution?" But, even this would be something I would happily overlook if it were not for the primary issue this game has.


The RNG in this game is AWFUL. So many runs are dashed against the rocks of fate unfavourable. At the beginning of the game there are so many new things and so many options that running out of items or getting dead-ended doesn't feel too painful. There are more mysteries to discover, more things to unravel, more puzzles to solve. You'll just Call It a Day and try again tomorrow. As the hours tick by and the runs increase, the mysteries dwindle. The puzzles narrow. There are a LOT of puzzles in the game, but if you are assiduous you will eventually reach a point where the amount remaining shrink. Now, every puzzle you want to engage with in some way requires several layers of RNG acting favourably for you. It is at this stage when this game begins to drag. The game feels sluggish. There are times where no matter what you do your progress is scuppered by events that are largely outside of your control. There are strategies in play that you can implement that reduce the likelihood of a run ending prematurely, but as the game is not 'skill-based', you can - and you WILL - be presented with room choices that will end your run irrespective of your preparations or considerations. 


I spoke to a friend about this game and I think they summed up my biggest criticism of this game better than my meandering semi-ramble could ever hope:

Blue Prince does not respect the player's time.

A 15 hour puzzle game and a 30 hour rogue-like mixed together to produce a 100+ hour waste of time. Is there another example of a game that mixes genres like that where the endproduct is SOO much less than the sum of its constituent parts?

The praise this game receives baffles me. 

It runs well, it looks nice and the premise is intriguing. Despite what promise it holds, the core gameplay loop seems designed to test player's tolerance for unforeseeable fail states. When entering a door, players choose one of three room blue prints to expand the level and continue exploration, with the goal of discovering the mansions mysterious 46th room. How interesting! Unfortunately, the three choices are rarely all viable, with costs attached to many rooms, alongside dead-end rooms that halt exploration; players first few runs are prone to end early. And that's it.

Supposedly there are cryptic puzzles, and I understand there's a story too. I wouldn't know. What's front loaded in this game is RNG-based trial and error and I cannot imagine any payoff being worth the frustration. While repetitive failure is a staple of Roguelite games, Blue Prince doesn't clearly communicate what the 'right' way to play is. It's surprisingly unforgiving. Maybe I've just been unlucky with my room draws, but luck even being a factor is incredibly off-putting.

I'm too late to ask for a refund, but if you're thinking of buying Blue Prince, do yourself a favour and watch some let's plays first. I don't think the positive reviews reflect the polarizing nature of this game.

I feel incredibly conflicted writing this review having just found Room 46. On the one hand this is an incredibly charming, beautifully realised game with some of the most original level design I've seen in years, and a particularly pretty art style. But the further I got into it, the further my wonder turned to frustration and near agony at how much disdain the game shows you at times as a player. I can't help but feel like it's a game that doesn't really respect your time as the hours tick by.

Your initial goal of reaching the antechamber drives you forward and you chase down that huge pay off of reaching it like beating a tough boss. When you finally hit that chamber you're presented with a basement key and realise actually it was a false climax, your actual goal lies elsewhere. It was a deflating feeling that should have been a triumphant high but I pressed on and got back into the rhythm. After stumbling upon the foundation room I finally found where the basement key needed to go and after a lot of bumps in the road I managed to get myself down there and was punching the air in satisfaction... only to hit a cog platforming puzzle. I played around with it but gradually my heart sank because I knew there was clearly something else I needed to do in another room to actually reach my goal, and had to end my run fruitless. 

I needed to move a minecart out of the way from the other side of the track which could only be done by draining the fountain. I know it's a puzzle video game but it doesn't help your frustration when you can clearly see how easily your character could squeeze around it in real life. The process of having a second false moment of success merge into another gruelling run of trying to draw the right rooms was really starting to grind me down by this point. I needed a pump room which also required me to draw a swimming pool and once you reach this point in Blue Prince where you've mentally solved the puzzle but are counting on RNG it becomes less compelling and more tedious. Maybe I was unlucky, or my drawing strategy was flawed, but it just took so long to finally get the pump room, with the boiler room adjacent to easily solve the puzzle (I believe there's a way to drain the fountain without the boiler room but I gave up trying to work out the combo). All of this culminated in a joy sapping experience where at times on the run to Room 46 I even questioned if I liked video games any more, it's a crazy thing to even type out but when it was hitting 2am and I'd hit another dead end because of bad draw luck it felt like such a waste of time. You're committing a lot of time to something which isn't making you feel good and you question whether the highs earn the lows.

When I finally got to the last room it couldn't help but feel anti-climatic because twice previously the big teased moment had been a false dawn. The narrative that surrounds the game is very imaginative but also convoluted and abstract; even after looking up the plot I was surprised by how unfamiliar it seemed to me having read pretty much every note and book I could find over 25 hours in game. It meant the cutscene at the end still felt more surreal than definitive and gave me more questions than answers.

I don't know quite why this game started to rub me up the wrong way so much but it did, and that's why I don't recommend it in the end, as technically impressive a game as it is. I think the crux of it is that lack of respect for time; the question is why do arbitrary extensions of the goal keep being thrown at you just as the prize seems in reach? The only answer I could find was to pad out the game time, which to puzzle fanatics may well be a joy but to me it replaced the sense of accomplishment with frustration. I don't in any way thing the game should end when you first reach the antechamber but I wish there was some kind of lasting pay off that made it feel like more of a success than a fake out.

In Hades, which also uses rogue like elements, your first time beating the final boss is such a euphoric and well crafted moment. I don't feel that same release in Blue Prince as marvellous as it can be at its best. The bottom line is unless you're very methodical and happy to embrace a game that moves the goalposts regularly, Blue Prince may well bring you more frustration than joy, as alas, it did I.

I subsequently spent some time with a game that respects my time more, which completely validated my decision to bail.  Recommend others don't get started unless you are really into grind.

You're also apparently supposed to just know from the start which things to screenshot etc, without any prompt to do so, because otherwise it will be impossible to remember in which room you read that random note that will be super important later to solve a specific puzzle in another random room.

I get that good games can be frustrating and that this is also a rogue-lite, but the "good" frustrating games are usually the ones where you keep going until you finally succeed and get reward for it, maybe in the form of progress. After just a bit over 10h I'm already so tired of this that I don't care about the story anymore, I just want the game to let me go further and actually feel like the time I'm putting into this is actually doing something. This is one of the first games in a long time that made me want to just quit and do something else with my time.

I'll probably play it more because I really want to believe it's going to get better and have some really interesting twists, but at this point it feels like I'm grinding just to get to a place where the game will be fun again. 

It's a shame because the game has such a cool style, you can feel the love that's been put into this. But I don't recommend it because if it is a puzzle game, then it should have puzzles that you can solve by your own merit, not random parts of ones that you need to have luck to even assemble.

RNG and puzzle game really don't fit together. No more than 2 hours into the game I'm already looking for mods/cheats that can deal with this RNG thingy. Even though I'm so far not "deep" into the game, after learning the core logic of rooms, I can totally PREDICT what will happen based on how typically rogue-like games annoy players: sometime I'll need a combination of rooms (maybe even a specific positioning of rooms) to solve or get the puzzle work. Since they are all based on RNG I'm expected to repeat part of the game over and over to roll a desired configuration, oh, and to pray that I have enough resources to proceed by that time. This is IMO in contrast with puzzle games which should have deterministic playthroughs, so this RNG design is no more than nonsense which obliterated my experience. Have a look at the nexusmod page, and think about why the top downloads are cheats and what things those players don't like.

The step count is also something that I don't understand. I totally understand that for a rogue-like design there must be something telling "nope this is it, time to reset". However, in this game there is always such a point of dead end even without this step count, for example, when no more puzzles can be solved or no more rooms can be drafted. Adding another layer of complexity for the identical functionality is utterly pointless. The only purpose I can think of it is to limiting the player from checking clues scattered around rooms or collecting resources in remote rooms - that is, annoying the player, if in plain words.

In addition there is way too much reading. Unlike the room series-like where reading is almost story or lore-oriented, in this game I have to read most of the text unless I'm playing against a walkthrough. There are also tons of puzzles that heavily rely on English, so localization will be next to impossible. In other words, the devs have never thought about non-English audience in the first place. Btw, these are only minor problems compared with the RNG issue.

In short, this game is not a "puzzle game" represented in a rogue-lite manner, but rather a rogue-lite game filled with puzzles. The puzzles by themselves are OK, though. I suggest: add cheating console commands to (1) eliminate resource restrictions; (2) specify which room to spawn next door; and (3) auto-solve minigame puzzles in each room once it was solved in previous playthroughs. Only by then this game can return to the purity of a true "puzzle game" (jigsaw-like room arrangement and puzzle-solving focused play style), freeing the player from the hassle and repeated work.

A rat in a Skinner Box can press a lever. If it receives a food pellet every time it pressed the lever, it will press the lever only when it is hungry. If it never receives a food pellet it will never engage with the lever anymore. If it randomly and infrequently receives a food pellet it will frantically keep pressing the lever.

Blue Prince is a random Skinner Box. It wastes your time away while you keep rerunning the game because "this time I'll crack it". I suspect that over time the RNG gets less hostile to keep you engaged. And it feels like you have achieved something. You didn't. You just spent time. 

If you like engaging with a random Skinner Box, this is your game.

Let me start by saying I love the concept of this game. I'm getting really tired of getting completely denied of progress becausue of the resource + RNG.

The game has many interesting mechanics and puzzles, which you can solve only by doing multiple runs. Most likely you cannot decide if you like the game after only 1-2 runs.

But after playing a while, it feels like actually knowing more mechanics and secrets of the game won't help you progress any further. You keep stumbling into these situations, where you can do everything right with the cards you've been given, but then lose just because of getting bad RNG once or twice.

Yes, RNG is one of the core mechanics of roguelikes, but I can't recall any other one, where in multiple (or most runs TBH) I've gotten actually good RNG in the beginning, using this for my benefit, and then suddenly be denied of progress completely mid-run. It doesn't give you the feeling of "oh, I could've played better" or "damn, that obstacle was a bit too difficult, but next time I'll get over it."

I'm currently on my 11th run, and still my first run was absolutely the best one (even with being completely blind of the game's mechanics and secrets before playing it myself). I've learned a lot after those other 10 runs, but I just can't progress, because of the RNG stopping me so often.

So in the end, the game feel like a glorified story game/walking simulator, where the roguelite elements keep you progressing completely, instead of testing your skills and knowledge.

So play this game, if you want to be led by the game and have the experience it decides. But don't play this game, if you want the feeling of getting over obstacles by yourself (Which in my opinion is one of roguelikes'/-lites' main points).

The game is as infuriating as it is addicting. It took me over 100 attempts (in-game days) to finally reach the antechamber (the objective that seems like "beating the game"). My issues are the following:

-Game speed is INSANELY slow. Insultingly slow. The slowest walking simulator you remember playing in the early 2010's walks twice as fast as this game. You need a mod to play the game at 2x speed (at LEAST), or you'll die of old age before you roll credits. Localthunk is a hero for giving a 4x speed in the settings for Balatro.
-The game is VERY often non-intuitive. I spent the first hour of the game reaching what every other video game would consider a "soft-lock" state (where you can't progress the game at all but it hasn't hard crashed), but no. That's how the game is supposed to work. When you lose a run and can't progress the house, the game doesn't tell you, you just have to hit START OVER. Again. and Again. Build 3 rooms, oops RNG says only dead ends, now start over. 

-What you need to understand is that this game is basically Tetris. Except instead of rotating pieces and getting to choose where they go, you can't rotate pieces, and you can't choose where they go, but you can choose between 3 pieces. You will spend hours building Winchester mansion-looking houses because RNG screws you over. You have to learn the Tetris pieces in the deck and intentionally use bad pieces to remove them from the pool. Which feels like a meta thing that other rogue-likes don't do. Comparing again to Balatro, which tells you what cards are in your deck. You should be allowed to access a database of all the rooms in-game so you know what's still available. Instead you're checking the wiki I guess.

-Meta progression is scant. Few and inconsistent ways to store tools and items. I can't count how many times I ended a run with a ton of keys, gems, and coins, got a soft-lock run, and was never offered the room that lets me stow those for the next run. All wasted.

As someone who loves puzzle games, I found this to be hugely disappointing. I was skeptical of the genre blend between roguelite and puzzle game to begin with, and the two hours I played did nothing to shake those feelings. Typically the fun of roguelites is how replayable they are thanks to random elements and unlockables, but here those qualities actively work against any kind of fun puzzle gameplay. I solved the same arithmetic puzzle four times in an hour, and also encountered a very generic true/false logic puzzle repeatedly. These puzzles are beyond basic and are not satisfying to solve, yet you get to reencounter them everytime you play, and cannot skip them since they reward you with consumables you need in order to progress. In one run I stumbled upon several safes, which were poorly hidden in various rooms (again, very unsatisfying to discover), however I had no way of finding the code. It may have something to do with a series of paintings on the wall, but the paintings may have been placed randomly, as they seem to be in other rooms. The game makes no effort to indicate either way, and ultimately I move on. Shortly after I find a note with a number written on it labeled "safe code". I run back to the first safe and input the code, and get no response (no visual or audio feedback at all). I then go back to the other safe and have the same experience. In a later run, I find that the note was written on red paper, which means that it's a lie. This isn't fun. This isn't rewarding. This is time wasting and frustrating.

In addition to the puzzling being extremely poor, the gameplay loop is also unexciting and boring. The "choose 1 thing from 3" roguelite gameplay is on full display here, and it sucks as much as it typically does. You will lose runs due to random chance, and then get to repeat the same generic puzzles all over again, only to be stonewalled once again by bad RNG. The encyclopedia of rooms is also shockingly small, meaning that you can expect to see the same rooms quite often (likely to make sure that the larger puzzle elements work). Trying to draft a path through the house is, to put it bluntly, not interesting or fun.

While I am not aware of exactly what it is, I know that at some point there is a larger meta puzzle that comes into play. I found no hints of this in my playtime, and while this element may redeem the game to some players, I don't see why I should have much faith in it when the basic gameplay is so poor. I've played other games with meta puzzles, but the thing that makes them work is that those games are also fun to play if you never find the bigger puzzle. 

Please, if you are thinking about playing this game, look at Fez, The Witness, Rise of the Golden Idol, Return of the Obra Dinn, or Tametsi instead. Any one of these games will offer a stronger hook, better game design, and more interesting gameplay.

After every mystery you uncover,

Every wheel that gets added gives you the chance to get new puzzles to uncover new mysteries.

Every win, you will get more coins.

Every win, you need more coins to be able to play.

Every win the wheels rotate slower.

Every wheel that gets added will also hamper your chances to win.

At one point you might solve a puzzle that gives you the chance to play on another smaller one-armed bandit.
On that smaller bandit, you can only play once before playing on the big bandit.
But that smaller Bandit is in another room.
Going to that smaller bandit in the other room will cost you coins.
Going back to your big bandit will cost coins.
And all you can win are more wheels, wheels that will be added to your big one-armed bandit.

Wheels that give you the chance to get new puzzles to uncover new mysteries.

Wheels that give you more coins when you win.

Wheels that will cost you more coins to play.

Wheels that will rotate slower still.

Wheels that will give you the illusion of progress.

Blue Prince makes a strong first impression: the mansion’s moody aesthetic, clean UI, and a soundtrack that sets the right tone. It looks nice enough. But after a few hours, the veneer wears thin and the design decisions start getting in the way of the fun.

I couldn’t see the point of the randomly generated room. It feels like noise rather than discovery, adding friction without meaningful surprise. Worse, the daily reset seems unfair and fruitless to continued exploring of the mansion; progress evaporates, momentum stalls, and you spend more time retracing steps than uncovering anything clever. When a game’s core loop is “explore → learn → build on what you learned,” clearing the board each day undercuts the whole appeal.

There are flashes of charm—occasional puzzles land, and the mansion’s layout hints at a deeper mystery—but the systems rarely cohere into a satisfying rhythm. The result is a beautiful house with too many locked doors and not enough reasons to keep knocking.

Verdict: Stylish, but structurally fussy. Not worth the RRP. If you’re curious, wait for a deep sale; if you’re here for sustained exploration and payoff, there are better mansions to get lost in.
